Owen and Claire spend the bulk of their non-Malta time consistently recreating the facial expressions that have become all too familiar, though of course, Owen does get to hold out his palm in an attempt at controlling dinosaurs. There is a well-timed small dose of John Williams' iconic score from 1993, but it's the musical work of composer Michael Giacchino who mostly guides us along the way.Credit goes to director Trevorrow for the multiple location shoots around the globe, which helps minimize the set pieces ... most of which disappoint. Especially surprising was the weak CGI effort in the mines as some of the characters end up where they shouldn't be. DNA manipulation run amok is perhaps the underlying theme, but we have to ask why this is ... all we really desire are cool dinosaurs and a story that makes sense. Despite the film's best shot coming at the end - a Mosasaurus underwater - we do hope that, in regards to continuing the franchise, Hollywood doesn't find a way.Opens in theaters on June 10, 2022.

I saw the reviews before going to see this movie, so I had low expectations, but I gotta say, this movie isn't that bad, in fact it's pretty good. It's a TON of fun, and the original characters add some life to this movie that felt missing from the other Jurassic World films. The plot is the only thing that kind of doesn't work, but even so it's not bad, it's just passable. The action scenes are amazing, and the adventurous globetrotting feel of this movie makes it stand out from the others. The dinosaurs, of course, are awesome, and there are some touching scenes with them here. In the end, it's kind of the dinosaurs themselves that are the emotional center of this film. Best Jurassic movie since The Lost World.

Jurassic World: Dominion (2022) is a movie we watched as a family in theatres last night. The storyline follows a world that is trying to adjust to dinosaurs being a regular part of every day life. Meanwhile an evil organization looks to exploit circumstances by creating genetically engineered locusts to destroy the Earths food so you need to rely on them to survive...oh, and they want to steal Hammond's cloned niece. It will take the heroes from every movie of the Jurassic Park series to save the day.This movie is directed by Colin Trevorrow (Jurassic World) and stars Chris Pratt (Guardians of the Galaxy), Jeff Goldblum (The Fly), Sam Neill (Event Horizon), Bryce Dallas Howard (The Help), Mamoudou Athie (Uncorked) and Laura Dern (Blue Velvet).This movie, unfortunately, it's about the same as Jurassic World: Kingdom. The dinosaurs and special effects are awesome. There's some tremendous species of dinosaurs and dinosaur battles, especially the last one. Unfortunately for the storyline, it reminded me of John Wick 3, just an excuse for dinosaur scenes like that John Wick was just an excuse for action scenes with a flimsy clich√© storyline. There were also too many subplots going on in here - some were fun and entertaining (black market and underground trade was well done, locusts and cloned child not so much). The acting was fine but the cast could have been way better utilized with better writing.Overall this was a fun popcorn flick as long as you go in with the right mind set. Think of it like watching Fast and Furious, Transformers and John Wick; no it's not going to be a good movie, but the dinosaurs are cool. I would score this a 6/10 and recommend seeing it once.

Please stop making Jurassic park films, the name is being dragged through the mud. The main ingredient missing in the movie is fear. The first Jurassic park movie held so much fear of these unknown large creatures that could kill us humans in a heartbeat, and there was also the awe factor of how amazing the dinosaurs were. Every character was at risk of dying in the movie and it was heart pounding to will them to live, and not all did.But Now, watching Jurassic World Dominion, I am faced with a movie that has no fear or awe in it. No one is going to die, and we all know it. No matter what situation, all the main characters are going to be safe without a doubt in our mind. The big grand dinosaurs are nothing compared to us smart and witty humans that have no issue surviving them... and on top of it they throw in these mission impossible fighting and running scenes that do not belong in this movie. And to push the viewer one step further the actors always look perfect. Oh did I just fall out of the sky in a plane crash? Well guess what, my makeup is perfect afterwords, not a scratch on me? I'm not shaken by that, why would I be? That is not realistic, it makes the movie feel cheap and phony. The visuals were awesome during the film, but everything else was terrible.

First of all, when I first watched the official trailer of the movie I really liked it and I was so hyped about it, because I really enjoyed the previous two movies. Eventually, it wasn't as good as I had imagined and it's probably the worst movie of the trilogy. The plot of the 3rd movie was very interesting, mysterious and kinda different then the two previous movies of the franchise. The storyline was kinda well-written and some parts were well-explained, but it wasn't as good as the previous movies. The characters were very interesting, well-developed and really likeable. The filming locations of the movie was the real world, because now the dinosaurs coexist with the humans. Also, it was a very intense movie and full of dinosaur attack scenes, but not as action-filled as the previous ones. The dinosaur's design was as good as the previous movies, the CGI effects were very well edited and they were kinda terrifying. Moreover, the duration of the movie was too long and it was kinda slow paced. In my opinion, it wasn't a nice conclusion of the trilogy, because I expected something way better. The killcount of the movie wasn't bloody, at all and most kills were done off-screen, so nothing explicit was shown. Overall, "Jurassic World Dominion" was just an average sequel, kinda adventurous and I would probably recommend it to my friends. Last but not least, I really hope they're gonna make a 4th movie!

I don't know what people were expecting with this movie and why many seem to be up in arms about it. I am a big fan of the first film and saw it in theaters as a child upon its release. For many, including myself, the magic of that first movie is never going to be topped and it's impossible to think it could be.That said, the second film has always been dull to me (and Jeff Goldblum seemed to be playing a different character than Ian Malcolm altogether). The third has solid moments but some silly ones as well. Jurassic World seemed to rejuvenate the franchise and was a good movie overall, but nothing mind-blowing in my opinion.Then we have Fallen Kingdom, which I believe is easily the worst in the series. Strange plot, terrible pacing, weird directorial choices left and right. The main characters and their motivations seemed completely different than what you would have expected from their portrayal in Jurassic World.That movie also ended with the concept of a world filled with dinosaurs - a point which people seem to be rolling their eyes about, now that Dominion has to address it.This is unfair. Dominion is a movie that must take the plot threads that are limply presented in Fallen Kingdom and then spin a sequel out of them. On top of that, it must weave in the cast of the beloved first film and make a satisfying conclusion out of both stories.And guess what? I think it accomplishes this, and much better than I expected it would. The movie is exciting, well-paced, well-acted, and has far fewer eyeroll moments than the critics would have you believe.At this point, I think you're either along for the ride or you aren't. If you're only casually aware of Jurassic Park and you go into this movie somewhat blind, it would probably seem like a mess of convoluted plot points. But if you're coming off of Fallen Kingdom, this feels like a breath of fresh air and a fun ride.I would honestly rank this movie as the second best Jurassic Park movie, behind the original. And Ian Malcolm's portrayal in this film is perfect, unlike what we got in Lost World. It's a joy to see.

Movies I've ever seen in my life. Almost walked out of the theater, but my wife wouldn't let me. Everyone involved in the making of this film should retire from their work immediately. It was that bad. Sorta like 99.9% of everything else outta the entertainment business in the last decade.

Now where have we heard this before? Why is it the Hollywood trend appears to be finding the balance of the better the special effects, the sillier the story.This one takes the biscuit. Throw in the compulsory wonderful /genius blm advert 'characters' to even further break down the fourth wall and basically it's only worth watching for the (albeit impressive) effects so bring your eyeballs but leave your brains at home.Was nice to wear the 3D specs again, although nothing really jumped out at me.

An absolute fail to remake some classic scenes from the 1st movie. There were plenty of flashback elements but obviously done really bad. It looked like amateur made fan movie on the whole. Sad for all the great actors to be part of this parody.

JURASSIC WORLD DOMINION (2022) **1/2 Chris Pratt, Bryce Dallas Howard, Sam Neill, Jeff Goldblum, Laura Dern, Isabella Sermon, DeWanda Wise, Campbell Scott, Mamoudou Athie, B. D. Wong. Underwhelming - and possibly final chapter - in the blockbuster sci-fi franchise imagines dinos now living amongst mankind while under threat from a sinister bio-tech organization (shocker) which reunites the first film's trio of heroes Alan Grant, Ellie Satler & Ian Malcom (welcome back Neill, Dern and Goldblum) while 'dinosaur whisperer Owen Grady (*eyeroll*) and on-and-off gal pal Claire Dearing (Pratt and Howard reprising the couple) are en route to save their surrogate daughter Sermon, who provides a DNA link uniting pretty much everyone. Filmmaker Colin Trevorrow (who co-scripted the janky screenplay with Emily Carmichael) returns as well to balance the CGI and practical f/x with some skill and finesse in spite of its tone deaf dialogue.

I have reached at a phase in my life where I have learnt to be unbiased in my judgement of films even if it features my favourite stars. But like everything other facet of life, this principle also has its exceptions - I cannot help but be biased about the Jurassic Park films and there are several factors contributing to that bias:
1. My love for films kick-started with "Jurassic Park" (the first film I had watched at a theatre, way back in 1994) and that film and most of its scenes have become iconic over the years - a feat unmatched by any monster film of the past and the present.2. Having watched the original in 1994, the child has ever since been fascinated by the jaw-dropping, awe-inspiring dinosaurs. They had occupied a world of fantasy for the kid who was by nature an introvert. From collecting dino toys to owning dino t-shirts, I have done it all and continue to do it now, when given a chance, as I am still preoccupied by these mighty beasts.3. The sequels and the spin-offs to the original have had hits and misses in them, never touching the iconic moments of the original but have always continued to be watchable even now. I didn't like "Jurassic Park III" but I have never overlooked it, having watched it multiple times as well. Despite the flaws, they define an integral part of my childhood and every new film is a stroll down the lanes of nostalgia for this 31-year old guy. They are special to me, no matter what.Jurassic World: Dominion takes place four years after the cataclysmic events of the previous film and the dinosaurs are out in the human world. They are colliding into one another and learning to live together as well. Metaphor for COVID-19? Yes, could be. The film also touches on issues like food scarcity and plagues and the side effects of bioengineering in agriculture. It is in some of these moments in the first half that the film suffers from pacing issues and from lack of being in a tight knot. But once the pre-interval scene comes up, the film changes track. The scene changes to the park and the essence of Jurassic Park is back. There are numerous dinosaurs, scene after scene, some new (like the Therizinosaurus, the Pyroraptor, the Atrociraptor, and the big daddy of them all - the Giganatosaurus) and some old (like the Velociraptors, the Tyrannosaurus Rex, the venom-spitting Dilophosaurus, Brachiosaurus, Triceratops, among many others) - a dream world for a dino lover like me. The cinematography is jaw-dropping and the mixture of special effects and animatronics seal the deal effectively well. Despite the flaws in the screenplay, the film is salvaged by the breathtaking second half. Among the actors, Bryce Dallas Howard gets the best character arc and newcomer DeWanda Wise turns in a commendable performance. But it was great fun to watch the OG cast - the dynamics between the trio of Alan, Ellie, and Ian can beat any newcomer, after all they are the heart of the franchise and it was worth having them to close the chapters on dinosaurs forever.

Much better than anticipated with all the criticism. I wouldn't say it's too long; they crammed a lot into 2 and half hours, it only felt long for the first 50min because it wasn't until then that any actual action occurred. We do get to see plenty of dinosaurs in that time, though, a lot in fact, as they had accumulated across the world and been processed/handled appropriately by the government. This they did really well on writing and execution. The whole Maisie situation was eyeroll heavy but not as bad as Fallen Kingdom in my opinion. Some of my biggest gripes were dinosaur behavior (a herbivore killing deer and challenging apex predators), characters not using their guns during standoffs with raptors, and the inaccurate design of the Giga. But hey, all in good fun, right? The action was abundant, even if the characters were invincible, Grant and Sattler had a lot of screentime, Malcolm too, Pratt was great and my favorite, Claire, possibly had all of the best scenes. New raptor designs were immensely appreciated, I just wish they had been involved in more than a predictable chase scene. The amount of animatronics and practical effects were shocking, I give major props to that; the dimetrodon sequence was amazing! Sure, the flick has its flaws and hiccups, but what JW doesn't? It felt like a sound conclusion to the series to me, though I still yearn for more.

With this much money and this many iconic actors coming back you would think they could make something good. What a complete 180 from the original movie. It was just sad watching all of the new Jurassic series. I wish the would start making movies like they used to. Take risks, hire people based on talent, START with an excellent story. Anyway do not watch this movie is you care about good story and good film making. This movie was just sad and hard to watch. It was all just pointless. It was all just boring. You didnt care. Colin Trevor needs to stop being allowed to make movies. He is probably one of the worst directors in the industry.

It is an entertaining, but long movie entry into the Jurassic World Series. It is intriguing, has good acting, and a story that prolonging itself as it can. You get to see how Mazie (young girl) was born, why is she so important to the scientists, and more dinosaurs as you can predict.

Horrible plot, Dinosaurs were simply windowdressing for a locust-movie and everything else was simply pandering to memories, hints at and copies from previous titles in regards to characters actions. I had to force my way through this one and it left me wondering. When they watched the final cut before release, how can they step back and be happy with what they've made?

LIKES:
The Comedy: The Jurassic Park series has always had some string of comedy sprinkled in the darker world of the survival pictures. Dominion goes a little more into this realm, working to make it very funny and sometimes in the modern style of more is better. Pratt and Goldblum are the primary haulers of the comedy, while the other characters sneak their own levels of laughs into the mix. Yet my favorite styles were some of the dinosaur moments and how the managed to make several of them have a little more human side and deliver that comedic punch to rock our worlds. Though forced a bit at times, the comedy really is decently done and feels back to being natural and well-placed like the first movies.Lots of Dinosaurs: It's a movie about dinosaurs and well you get dinosaurs... where others have shown their cards and given you a few species to enjoy and get glimpses of, Dominion really makes this supposed final act, have all the dinosaurs that you could want in this short run time. While some of them are the classic monsters you remember, there are other species from various eras that arise from the shadows and most of them feel just as sinister and destructive as you hope for in this series. So for those tired of the typical thunder lizards, you'll be in for a treat at the variety the movie brought with it.The Musical Score: Hands down another great lineage to this movie, the musical score is certainly one that still gives me goosebumps when I hear it boom over the speakers. Like the sound editing that brings the roars to life, the sixth part of the saga has the powerful orchestra work to add emotion to the scene and pull you into the full experience. Softer tones accompany or proceed the pounding orchestra blast that this series does super well. It's part of the movie theater experience worthy tone of this movie series and one of my favorite parts of the movie.The Pace: While certainly not the target pace of the first film, Dominion manages to still keep the action going and keep things moving. For all the story elements this movie juggled, it did not do a half-bad job for me in them working it to remain entertaining. From the opening moments that sum up the events before to getting into the Dinosaur action and solutions, it really just keeps a steady pace without dawdling too much on the truth. Again, the result is an entertaining adventure for fans of the series to enjoy and just get more Dinosaur carnage and rampaging on the screen.The Acting: While certainly not the most unique or Oscar worthy in terms of roles and performances, the movie's repertoire of actors and actresses accomplishes the fun I like to see in these movies. Pratt is Pratt, he's goofy, but action hero epic, as he does his best to tame the primitive and fearsome beasts that are on the screen. He's the typical hero role we've come to love in him, and he has some great moves to finish this series off. Howard is probably the one with the most dynamic range in this film, her character getting a lot more time and scenarios than other characters at this time. As a result, she accomplished much in her character's growth and ability, really selling the emotions for the most part and giving me more to like about Claire while avoiding going too far down the stoic warrior path. As for Dern, she's a master of her trade, and I liked the new Ellie that was still the same quality components we got in number one, but still adding some new qualities that shows what she has been doing for the last three decades. As for the rest of the group, they do a great job with the parts handed and there are too many to go through given how loaded the film is. However, the summary is: Neal is great if a bit underutilized, Sermon is funny and replays the role quite well, Wise is tough, funny, and reminiscent of the American pilot trope from Spielberg films, while Goldblum accomplishes much in that same steal the show moment you love.The Character Use: While nowhere near perfect, Dominion does a better job than I intended of keeping the cast involved in the entire film, at least the human cast. With all sorts of characters to try and pull into one final act, you have a lot of stories, actors, and teams to try and keep ingrained in the tale. Old cast may not be the most involved at times, but hit at the moments that matter and give the loyal fans everything they need to wrap up this portion of the Jurassic World series, including laughs and a few tropes that you might be wanting to see. As for the new ones this part of the series, they get a lot more of the time and again accomplish the goal of expanding the story, whilst still being fun avatars to live through in this world.The Chase Scene/Action At Times: The trailers showed an exciting scene of dinosaurs and bikes, and you know what... it accomplished it big time. I loved the race through the streets, a feeling of Mission Impossible meeting Dinos as they raced for survival in this CGI world. I absolutely loved this moment and felt it was the highlight of the action for this movie and the true climactic experience, if not a little cheesy at times. Other action scenes felt very part of the world, and there is a few big beast fights that you'll be wanting to see that really have some fun qualities to them, including one epic finish. As such, the action does accomplish its role for this series and should have the extreme fanatics stomping their feet in delight.The Graphics: By far, the ability of studios to make dinosaurs come to life is still something that, to quote Laura Dern, "you never get used to!". For me, I love seeing the beasts come to life, finding the balance between computer graphic use and animatronics to bring these ancient creatures back to life. With modern technology, the computer work has never looked better in textures and stationary shots, while the robots are still impressive, but a little more artificial at times, though still doing a fantastic job of making them pop off the screen.The Action At Times: Again, more beasts and humans, means a bit more of other qualities being scattered and the action is again one of those moments. Prior to the new trilogy, Jurassic Park's action was mostly about survival in the world of the largest carnivores. While some of that does exist, Dominion seems to have diluted most of it to the modern day action, leading to some great moments mentioned above, but also weaker elements you had hoped would be a bit more intense in the long run. The result is less intense action moments and feel like there are less stakes to be had.The Subplots: Characters have to have arcs and backgrounds to be engaging right? Well, Jurassic World: Dominion does have that, only with so many characters in the mix they are a little diluted and bland. Both old and new have things they can certainly pursue, but sadly don't do well with everybody on the screen. The new pilot who lives life dangerously, Malcolm's story over the last two decades of what's happened with him, even Ellie to an extent all feel very simplistic given what it could have been. It's not horrible, and checks the box for complete, but for those invested in the characters, don't expect the most thought out character plots for others.The Main Story: By far the weaker of the tales, was indeed the story of Jurassic World Dominion. Painting a very broad stroke and keeping all the characters in it, this movie is not quite the focused feature the others have been. While most merely just want a survival film filled with dinosaurs and more dinosaurs, others again want to be engaged with the film. Again, for me, this film diluted both and the great overarching story is a little more political story than actually engaging feature. The villain is simplified and boring, the solutions to the problems almost as dry and uncreative, as they simply work through things. Throw in the predictability, the lack of suspense, and the statistical probability of what is going to happen and the plot becomes less impressive in favor of the flash in a pan gimmick.The Lack of Suspense and Terror: By far, the lack of suspense and terror is what I was missing in this film. Jurassic World has lost so much of the thing that drew us into the first series, the intensity of surviving the next encounter and how they got out, racking us with terror as the fake monsters tried to tear their way to food. For me, that feeling has been gone since number three, replaced with an almost action/drama feel that while it has it's good parts, is still not the same edge it once had. I did not find myself talking to the screen encouraging them to go, go, go like I once did and that was a bit sad for me really. It was this lack of intensity that II think was the weakest component of the movie and the lack of intensity is the component that really made the movie drawl in my case.The VERDICT:The supposed last installment of the great dinosaur movie was entertaining and fun, with the effects being the main thing to experience in theater. It juggles the cast well, makes for a fun use of multiple dinosaur species, and breaks open the music and technology to craft the world. It handles the cast decently well and keeps that engaging pace you want in a movie like this, devoid of any complex plot of processing. However, even the simple adventure like that lacks the bite of the original series, putting almost too much in one film that it spreads the quality across the two-hours unevenly and in many ways less than the potential it had. The biggest disappointment with me was in fact the lack of terror and suspense, this component almost washed out entirely given the predictability of the tale. So, factoring that in my scores of the movie are:Action/Adventure/sci-fi: 7.0
Movie Overall: 6.0.

If I were the guy being paid 6 figures to watch a movie and determine if it was ready for theaters or not, I'd have quit just to avoid finishing this train wreck.No fluid plot, horrible consistency (my girl outran a velociraptor that then outran a speeding vehicle), everything about this was just aweful. The silliest Fast&Furious mock-up doesn't compete with how absolutely attrocious this movie was. Even the dinosaurs special effects seemed to have taken a dive in quality? This is the movie version of taping a banana on a wall and calling it abstract art, and literally paying millions for it.

Loved it ! Absolutely loved it! Definitely recommend this movie to any fans ! It's amazing the span of 30 years and it pays homage to all the movies.

I always enjoy these type of movies because I don't take them seriously. I like how casual and fun they feel. But this one was so full of cliches, predictable, and had such a weak plot that it lost me. The dialogs also were so bland and don't even get me started on the hand thingy. You know protagonists don't get hurt or die in movies like this, but it was so ridiculous the way they would survive that it makes the dinosaurs look dumb. Like, they have to do the breathing slow thingy, yelling at them, and do all kind of show offs but when it actually gets to the point of attacking the humans they are suddenly all saved at the last minute. Also everybody seems to be in the right place at the right time somehow. The movie's logic is very faulty too. Such a waste of budget and time. It was so bad that I created account in this site just to trash it. I almost stopped the movie but was falling asleep so I figured what the hell, let's just either give in to Morpheus or watch the end (after all, at least I wanna see how it ends).

Haven't seen it, haven't put a score, but just clicked on all 10/10 reviews and what a surprise that the only review those users have ever written are of this movie. I'll just leave it at that. Those reviews are obviously too shallow to be credible, but it's just sad.

Jurassic park was from the beginning an adventure story, with likeable characters and an anti-corporate message - incoorporating dinosaurs. This movie fits the bill. Some plots were a little iffy, but overall you have a great cast, some callbacks and motivation for every character. Even new characters, that are not just bland. That is some achievement in and on itself. So basically everything that the star wars franchise aims to achieve, but fails.Action is great and almost nonstop, camera, editing, practical vs cgi. The only thing that i am missing are the spielbergian pauses which let the information sink in and make the anticipation of what is to come even greater.As far as franchises go, slightly below marvel, well above star wars.

Even OG cast couldn't save the atrocious storyline. I guess the writer completely missed the mark on what we fans were expecting. The last movie Dinosaurs escaped to mainland and now humans and dinosaurs will need to coexist. It's like the writers didn't even see what happened in Jurassic Park part 2 lost world where T-Rex caused havoc when loose on mainland. This movie should've been more of an apocalyptic feel, humans trying to survive, Government/Armies failing, safe zones being breached and overall carnage where the OG cast somehow ends up reuniting to come up with a plan to save human species.Instead we get the same crap as the last 2 movies, a fancy secure building that gets breached, a rich greedy CEO, and everything just falling apart as usual. No purpose for OG cast to be there. Super lazy writing and screenplay. No originality feeling. Felt like a hotpodge cash grab mess.On positive side, visuals were stunning.

Did it survive or did the worms get it? Were there more perfect ears of corn for them to eat? Really felt the story was incomplete and I find myself wondering....

Jurassic World: Dominion opened in theaters this weekend. It is the highly anticipated sixth installment in the Jurassic Park franchise. In Dominion, we find out whether the dinosaurs, who were released into the world at the end of Fallen Kingdom, have been integrated into the greater society and what effect their presence has on the broader ecosystem. It's been almost 30 years since we were first introduced to dinosaurs in modern times; but, six films later, are we still in awe of the scientific feats of DNA splicing and cloning? Here's whether going back to Jurassic World is worth all of that anticipation.Jurassic World: Dominion brings back Owen Grady (Pratt) and Claire Dearing (Howard), who are raising the teenage clone, Maisie Lockwood (Sermon). They are protecting her from evil corporate interests who seek to capture and study her for their own nefarious reasons. Also, Elli Sattler (Dern) and Alan Grant (Neill) are back to investigate a potential ecological disaster brought on by genetically modified locusts rabidly devouring the world's crops. Then, there is Ian Malcolm (Goldblum) and Ramsay Cole (Athie) as fixtures of the corporation, Biosyn, which is at the center of all of these machinations. There's also a dynamic pilot, Kayla Watts (Wise), and a manipulative CEO of Biosyn, Lewis Dodgson (Scott). Oh man, did I forget anything? Um... prehistoric ravenous hijinks ensue.Okay, as you can see, there is a lot going on in Jurassic World: Dominion. It's not necessarily complicated, but it is a lot to follow. These Jurassic Park movies always have a bit of an issue getting bogged down explaining the science of this all. In Dominion, they have to talk about genetic splicing and cloning and ecology, and it just goes on and on. Sattler and Grant are focused on stealing the DNA of these destructive locusts to prove that Biosyn is evil. Owen and Claire are focused on protecting Maisie from Biosyn. In a sense, it feels like so much is going on that there is not enough time for the characters to run and scream from the dinosaurs. That's the unfortunate part if you really like that aspect from the original.Despite these reservations of the plot, the movie does have its exciting parts. There are dinosaur chases through the streets, through the jungle and through the Biosyn facilities. DeWanda Wise plays a tough-as-nails, wisecracking pilot, who seems to be the most competent of all of our characters. She gets good one-liners and has a magnetic personality. Her presence adds a lot of energy to what could become stale. I'll also note that the legacy characters of Sattler, Grant and Malcolm give exactly what you want. It's like no time has passed at all. The nostalgia is very high and they effectively scratch that Jurassic Park itch.Ultimately, Jurassic World: Dominion is an enjoyable, escapist summer blockbuster. The problem here is that there is too much going on and it doesn't exactly all come together. There are probably too many characters that distract from the main attraction - the dinosaurs. Nevertheless, there are good dinosaur chases and exciting moments with a great new character played by DeWanda Wise. While I wouldn't call Jurassic World: Dominion essential, it certainly is good enough for a matinee viewing, so get your bowl of popcorn.

Most of this film is how can we hurt the dinosaurs or have them hurt each other. No character has growth, no positive development through the story. Last movie was kill all the dinosaurs in a volcano eruption and watch them die and this time, lets put them all in a sanctuary and then burn it down! Why the constant need to kill all the dinos? This crew should really be able to do better by this point. Very unimpressed.

What a horrible movie. How much did they spend? All the main charactors did a lousy job in acting. After about 20 minutes I saw four actors looking into the camera (they are supposed to avert or close their eyes). Many of the secondary actors did a nice job, but it is obvious their scripts were poorly written. The best actors in this movie are all the dinasaurs. They did a great job. I am so proud of them.Can I just say stupid, predictable, self-centered kid as usual. One minute on screen and she's complaining, yelling, doesn't care about anyone, etc. Doesn't any of the Hollywood script writers have nice, polite, courteous kids??Is this movie worth watching for all you adults with kids out there. NO. The dinasaur action is great. After that, it is dumb, a poor example for what you want your kid to be, at every corner, it is so predictable AND unrealistic in almost all the action sceens. Just stupid.But if you have laundry to do, make dinner, vacuum, clean the windows, than this is the movie for you for background noise.Thank you for your time.

Another generic Jurassic Park movie full of bad CGI.Actors are good, but the CGI makes the movie look tame and unrealistic.I wish they made the Jurassic Park movies like the first two movies. More practical effects as it looks more realistic (compare T-Rex or Velociraptors from the first movie with this... This was amazing. On the genetic aspect the movie might be thin but on the ecological aspect this movie hits hard. The way it depicts the beauty of evolution and the importance of coexistence is incredible. Coexistence is something humanity needs to do with the rest of the planet to achieve balance and prevent all the world threatening problems. I know that there are a lot of negative reviews about this movie but what I am saying is this movie conveys a really tough message. It is a true science fiction film not like the superhero movies which are made just for entertainment. It not just a movie it's an emotion.

Ofcourd science fiction needs you to have a open mind. However there is a fine line between down right ridiculousness and science. This movie is so far over that line that it becomes unbearable to watch even with a open mind. Want to see a good jurassic park movie, rent the original!

Huge fan of Jurassic Park. Loved the story line and how they were successfully able to connect the past and new characters so well. This movie is everything I expected it to be: loud, dumb, and over the top action packed. I was neutral about this movie, it's so bad that it's almost good. What definitely worked for this movie was bringing back characters from the original films. I enjoyed seeing Neil and Dern along side Dallas and Pratt as well as the newcomers, Wise and Athie. However, a lot didn't work, like the storyline. It's generic and I expected much more. The dinosaurs are almost an after thought in this storyline, placed second to gigantic locusts (yes, silly, I know). Not horrible, but wasted opportunity. I would have preferred the movie expanding on humans living with dinosaurs in a modern world and exploring the moral and ethical debates that go along with it. It briefly touched on that but didn't dive in before creating some bogus plot about a corporation out to disrupt the food chain. Could have had some thought provoking yet terrifying and majestic scenes instead of the over utilized "evil corporation tries to take over the world" plot.

In 1993 Steven Spielberg's 'Jurassic Park' was an awe-inspiring spectacle like relatively few pictures can claim. For however well made subsequent films were made, in retrospect it's not wrong to say that the franchise kind of feels like B-movies writ large, like what SyFy original movies might look like if they had the largest of budgets and best of all resources. When the first trailer dropped for 'Jurassic World Dominion,' whatever else might end up being true of the picture, at least in concept it struck me as the dinosaur movie we've been waiting thirty years to see. To have read more about the production, and to have finally watched the finished product, this is even more true than I could have hoped. This isn't to say that JWD is perfect by any means, but of course it's incredibly well made, and acted, and for the most part very well written. It's smarter and more thoughtful than the average blockbuster, and if it falters along the way, it's not for lack of effort, but maybe just too much.What's most notable is how very different this picture feels compared to its predecessors - obviously part and parcel with the scenario. Substantial portions of the narrative would fit neatly into any big-budget thriller, with flavors of Action, Political, and Sci-Fi at varying points. In these facets and as well in quieter moments of exposition or reflection, major themes emerge which are painfully true and relevant to real life. 'Dominion' explores balance in the natural world; humanity's quarrelsome relationship with nature, and our attempts to coexist with it or bend it to our will; the abuse, destruction, and mismanagement of wildlife; science without ethics; idealism confronted with lack of control, leading to profound regret (something I can readily identify with); extreme, egregious corporate malfeasance and dodging of responsibility; man-made ecological calamity and impending extinction level events; and more. It's very noteworthy and very important that the plot also broaches the topic of GMOs - and not the nonsensically alarmist tripe about genetically modified food being bad for people and animals (news alart: all crops and livestock since the advent of agriculture has been genetically modified), but the real harm of GMOs, which is corporate monopolization of the food supply. These are all notions which have been touched upon in other stories, only in this instance, each and every one has been twisted together with dinosaurs.There's so very much that filmmaker Colin Trevorrow and co-writer Emily Carmichael have tried to let this feature say, be, and do. To their credit, for as towering and arguably bloated as the narrative is, it is cohesive, coherent, and complete; engaging, and satisfying. Every aspect of the screenplay is filled with gratifying intelligence, blending together the inflated genre romp sensibilities of the most highfalutin sci-fi adventure bombast with stark, gnawing themes; fantasy violence with realist human drama (or maybe one should say terrestrial drama); action sequences with garnishes of scientific fact, theory, and jargon; ham-handedness, sincere humor, thrills, and emotional investment with, yes, awe and wonder. Such grand ambition is, ultimately, also the chief weakness of the film. There's so very much that 'Dominion' wants to say, be, and do, and it may well have been to the benefit of the story, and the themes, to split this almost three-hour extravaganza into multiple pictures. The amalgamation as we see it is better than one could have hoped for, and done very well, yet there's unquestionably a sense that everything is jam-packed too tightly, disallowing every component part to receive the treatment it fully deserves. There's not one idea herein that itself couldn't have been expanded into a full-length film.Still, if that's the most significant criticism to lay at the feet of a hulking monstrosity like a sixth Jurassic Something movie, then I'd say it's doing pretty well for itself. Yes, there are instances when the scene writing or dialogue borrows from previous entries, 1993's progenitor especially. (In the spirit of generosity, one might say such moments are an homage.) There are also instances when the intended thrills become so over the top that SyFy might after all be the best point of reference, and the employment herein of Owen's trademark training gesture is 100% gauche. None of this is anything we wouldn't expect from the average blockbuster, however, so one can only take such matters with a grain of salt, or a stiff upper lip, or whatever other colloquialism one prefers. And meanwhile, in every other way, 'Dominion' is just as well made as one would assume of such a major motion picture event. The cast is great, bringing to tremendous life the parts they have with all the skill and sincerity they can muster. Whether animatronics or CGI, all the creatures look outstanding, and so do all the other effects, and the stunt work. The production design and art direction are downright exemplary. I admire Michael Giacchino's score, despite those places where it too blithely imps John Williams' pre-established themes. Lighting, direction, John Schwartzman's cinematography - all exquisite. This is the result of all the accumulated knowledge and experience of how to create a movie of this nature, on this level.At length, I do very much enjoy 'Jurassic World Dominion.' Whatever one's impetus for watching, I think it's well worth it, including simply the silly, baseline popcorn-chomping entertainment and satisfaction of the climax, and even the entirely all too easy resolution the ending represents. Its strengths and its faults are equally clear, I think, but by all means, on the balance this is a highly enjoyable sci-fi adventure flick. In fact, I'd love to say that I like it even more than I do, but the rational part of my brain tells me that the feature's favor of Most Blockbuster Fun over Best Storytelling Judiciousness decrees a measure of reservation. Even at that - though imperfect, I had a fantastic time watching. Second only to 'Jurassic Park,' this is almost certainly the best installment in the franchise. Even at its worst and most self-indulgent there's a lot to love here, and I'd have no qualms about recommending it to just about anyone, but especially those with an especial fondness for the '93 film. What else is there to say? If you have the chance to watch, 'Jurassic World Dominion' is worth three hours of your time.

Honestly disappointed. I went in with low expectations, but this movie didn't even meet them. Yes, the dinosaurs were pretty cool and had great animation. It is not good enough to save the atrocious plot of this movie. I was ready for the movie to be over an hour in and felt bored most of the movie. All of the tension was forced and it was so predictable! To the point where I could count down from three to my wife to predict a larger dinosaur would pop out. I'm thankful that this movie brought my wife and I closer over our shared laughter at the ridiculous plot. I won't see these movies in theater any longer, I'm so glad it was free.

I saw the ratings here on IMDB and waited for it to stream instead of seeing it in theaters. I regret that decision. It was a fairly decent movie. I'd say that the story line used a lot of elements that I've already seen in other movies and wasn't original such as the evil corporation. Also, the movie was a bit too long. I was expecting more of an "End of the World" vibe and it was certainly lacking in that department. That being said it doesn't deserve less than a six rating. I give it a seven. I love that they brought back so many actors from the original Jurassic Park and the urban scenes were really cool. There just needed to be more and they just barely missed the mark.

First of all, I love Pratt and Neill (and the rest of the cast) but they need a good story line. Dominion does not that. Very weak and one bizarre scene after another... see Maverick instead if you are seeking sentiment. SKIP!

Colin Trevarrow has hit the final nail on the franchise's coffin by deviating from the central dinosaur themed storyline, with bland dinosaur shots, introducing new uninteresting characters and a weak antagonist. The movie takes inspiration from modern day kaiju movies where the characters are secondary to the primary monster duels which has greatly affected the orginal franchise's plot and character based storyline. The movie could have been directed better by Michael Bay with more explosions and no dinosaurs. The movie makes dinosaur lovers grind their teeths in frustration. Overall a disappointing conclusion to a great franchise.

Unlike JW Fallen Kingdom which featured amazing classic horror elements this movie doesn't present something new to the franchise and that's not bad but it could have done something better.Instead of feeling like a dinosaur movie with action and adventure it feels like an action movie with dinasaurs in it.*Minor spoiler incoming:
JW Fallen Kingdom ended in a high note and it settled the ground for a great third movie, instead of focusing on how the world deals with dinasaurs they focused in Teenage Mutant Bugs... for some reason??Still, it's a fun movie and it was great to see Sam Neill and Laura Dern once again, Sam Neill steals the show with his charming, grumpy performance as Dr. Alan Grant.

The movie was full of exciting and fascinating effects (as usual), but the storyline seemed too forced, the original trilogy's adventure/fantasy vibe has gone totally, transformed into a blockbuster action movie, full of clich√®s and overused elements. Forced and fabricated character developments, or no change at all. New, seemingly exciting, charismatic, but pretty much expected characters along with old, returning characters, who have acted as 'reminders' of the original concept of the movie. The story is still unfinished, could be continued with some new twist, what can be said about this - and the two previous - movies. The acting was average, neither horrible, nor astounding, as expected from a movie like this. Overall, it was exciting and fun to watch, but looking at it more closely, the movie didn't really have a point, it has a strong message though - the same message that appeared in every 'Jurassic Park' movie: do not interfere with nature's laws. The sensible outcome - according to this movie - is symbiosis and peaceful cohabitating. Humanity's greed and curiousity will never change, but it can be 'cured'. However, in order to achieve that, we need certain punches from life, or else we'll never learn from our mistakes - suggests the movie (series).

This was just awful. We ended up counting how many times Chris Pratt holds his hand up to the dinosaurs. Jurassic Park was MAGIC. This was a bad gas station bathroom in comparison. Do not waste your money.

The first half an hour or so is a bit messy as the film has so many storylines going in different directions. Eventually the film picks up and the actions scenes are well done (although a bit repetitive) . Dont expect anything too complex or innovative, but its a fun popcorn film.

Though many of us may feel including me may feel sometimes that story is not that good but I will highlight Pros and Cons that I observed.PROS:
Graphics, CGI, Sound effects and all other tech used were the best then all previous titles of the franchise.This is better then most of the recent dino titles of other studios too in last 5 years, their story and graphics both were very worst then even this title like dinosaurs just freed from some where and running in the city and nothing else. So this Jurrassic movie is still better then most titles of same genre in last 5 years.CONS:
Story was not that good of the level of Jurrassic Park 1 or 2.Missing of horror, scare and, nostalgia of the level of previous sequels. The horror when a person or child is trying to save himself from unpredective dinosaur was missing here.

My 8 years old son loved the entire movie. He likes the raptors and the dynasours fights.As for me who watched all the previous ones it felt it is just purely commercial addition. They brought the old cast back with no clear role (compared to Spider-Man no way home where it was funny and has a purpose.).Overall still entertaining for new generation.
With the exception of a few good cast offerings this is a sorry mess of cliches and retread action and not worth your time! Some scenery shots are great but fail to save the effort!

I guess I care more about a plot (it was all over the place so basically there wasn't one), the original Jurassic Park magic (zero here just a show and tell of beasts and the exact same escape situations you've seen 100 times before), the acting (the little girl was HORRIBLE, Chris Pratt was wooden and seemed irritated that the other actors were in the movie, Laura Dern thought she was in a fashion show instead of a movie, Jeff Goldblum was just plain weird and must have gone off script so the film editor hacked up his dialogue). All of those in a movie are distracting and not enjoyable.The only good things were Sam Neill at 74 looked AMAZING and I loved this black lady who was a pilot (yet she only had about 8-minutes of screen time).Also, I absolutely hate it when a movie preaches to me and then ends the movie with what they THINK is an original, profound statement that you've seen and heard a 1,000,000 times before which was - "we can all get along and live in harmony no matter how different we are". Yawn.

Been super hyped and left super impressed. Wasnt surprised about dodgson being a replaced actor though and a menace and dumb***. Also i dont understand the woke negativity of jurassic world 3. As i was completely fine with it and not seeing what the critics saw. The story was brilliant and thrilling and very action packed and menacing. And very adorable. Problem being it was more about crickets and the girl

This is a boring, confusing instalment of a once beloved franchise. There's barely any dinosaur scenes? Not substantial, edge of your seat, cinematic dinosaur scenes that we've come to love. Very boring, no real storyline.

It's a good film... all things considered. The problem is that people are judging this movie not on what it had to follow... the previous film was horrible! If I produced themes and ideas that should not have been introduced. So... then you have to sequel it... well... this is what you get! The previous movie introduced cloning, a girl that was allowed to do something really stupid at the end, a character that has never been mentioned... it was bad! This film had to one... follow that and make up for the idiocy that it entailed... and be its own thing. It did that admirably! The old and new casts were on hand! They wrapped up storylines. There were some really good action scenes and beautiful scenery and dinosaurs. So... before you start casting stones, try to relate to the task they had.

Jurassic World Dominion a fitting end to a epic trilogy of jurassic sized movies, almost a avengers style sized movie that brings the new trio and old trio together in an attempt to save humanity on the brink of extinction.Upon reading reviews and reports I was sceptical about going to see this expecting dissatisfaction and disappointment and but got a rollercoaster end to a epic movie franchise. I won't be relying on movie reviews to see future cinema movies.Thrillingly exciting with epic turns and twists at every turn. A final curtain call on the jurassic era of cinema films. It is unrealistic too drawn out the plot is lousy and seems non existent. It just has scenes that are action packed yet unsatisfying. The timing makes it more absurd. The lines are so vapid. The stars featured do not distract me from how bad it is.The most original things are little noticable things that still do not make it worthwhile such as a flying motorcycle and people sneaking into a prohibited area. It is sickening. I am glad that I was treated to this garbage but disheartened that I had to sit through it. I recommend skipping it!

Four years after Isla Nublar was destroyed, dinosaurs now live-and hunt-alongside humans all over the world. This fragile balance will reshape the future and determine, once and for all, whether human beings are to remain the apex predators on a planet they now share with history's most fearsome creatures.The movie is driven by action and visual effects, with little care given to things like character development or a well-written plot. The pace is fast, and the movie is exciting, but it's forgettable. The dialogue is often cheesy, and the acting is just okay with Sam Neill, Jeff Goldblum, and Chris Pratt phoning it in. There are a few themes that pop up such as the dangers of messing with nature, but they are quickly abandoned in favour of more action.Jurassic World Dominion is a movie that is best enjoyed as a mindless popcorn flick. It's not going to win any awards, but it's entertaining enough. If you're a fan of the franchise, you'll enjoy it. If you're not, this movie isn't going to change your mind.

First off this feels like a mission impossible movie with dinosaurs. LOL!The animation on this is horrible as well. The puppets are just as bad. The original movie that was made 30 years ago had better animation and puppets. What is going on?They charge us full cinema prices but they skimp on animation? I'm done.Chris Pratt, what are you doing man? Enough is enough. You are an A list movie start. Don't sell out.

The movie was fine nothing special. We get to see dinosaurs as if we lived with them.You need to remember this is the 6th dinosaurs movie like it doesnt really have anywhere to go to be special.Enjoy it for what it is the 6th movie about humans bring dinosaurs back to life and now they live amongst us.

I took ten 12yo boys to this movie to kick off summer vacation and we almost left we were all so bored. My son & I loved the other movies but this was embarrassing. Can't believe the corny dialog. No story. What a waste. Waited a year and a total disappointment. Surprised all of the actors signed on, I know its $ but :/

When I think of Jurassic Park film, I remember the cinematography
masterpiece of the first part that starts especially in the middle of the movie. Which was the accepted effect of a movie in the 2 previous years . (though not the impression that remains in imitation). In the Jurassic Park 1993, none of the dinosaurs change into form, but the behavior that the characters emit in front of it creates an image of them in the mind. Maybe that's why we hardly feel such a void. . The most powerful sequence of jurassic world 2022 is when one of the dinosaurs looks at the surface of the water,like the most powerful sequence of jurassic park 1993 when looks at the car. Here too, none of the dinosaurs transform into a form. The brilliance of Spielbergto definition the narrative covers the Plot's flaws in Jurassic Park. Of course, I think that after some time, Spielberg himself came to the conclusion to use the sense of humor, but this sense of humor or caricature or darkness or the softness aspect should be done in the form of dinosaurs. Technically spectacular, but bit disappointing . . .Visually, perhaps the best yet in the artform of bringing dinosaurs to life. No problem with the suspension of disbelief there, especially with the added details of feathers, and other such anatomically precise renderings.But the story and acting, well, more than a bit disappointing.It seems they were trying too hard to play up the nostalgia and humorous dialogue woven into this. As for generic family viewing, this really is more of a movie for kids, with the parents and adults getting their layers of content almost as more of an afterthought.The one character that really stood out was DeWanda Wise's "Kayla", the gritty, been around the block a few times pilot who loves her flying machinery, and takes life as it comes.The usual suspect crew from the previous films in the series gave the story continuity, but the "magic" just wasn't there. Not sure how to put this exactly, but it just seemed canned, forced, clicheic, to the point where you could tell what their next line was going to be long before they said it.Isabella Sermon did as good a job as can be expected being the young "Maisie", trying to discover the real truth about who she is, where did she come from and so on.The most unfortunate was Jeff Goldblum, who could have been given much better material to work with, but was cast in this very narrow caricature that he had to be confined to.The actual story itself was a bit odd, not so much about dinosaurs living in a human world, but about the evil BioSyn corporation and swarms of giant locusts wreaking havoc upon the civilized world. I get the implications suggested, but it was more than a bit preachy, depicting the popular "woke" notion of evil biotech saturated with corruption and ill intent. The ending was Pollyannaish to an extreme, but again, aimed at kids for the most part.This could have been so much more than what it turned out to be, but then again it could have also been worse.If there is a next one of these, maybe they'll get it closer to what it could become.

"Jurassic Park Dominion" (2022 release; 147 min.) is the 6th (and last?) movie in the Jurassic Park franchise, and concludes the Jurassic World trilogy. I typically start my movie reviews with a very brief description of how the movie opens plot-wise, and I'm going to skip that in this instance, as the plot of "Jurassic Park Dominion" strains credibility in every which way. So let me get to my main comments instead."Jurassic Park Dominion" is written and directed by Colin Trevorrow, who also did the honors on the first Jurassic World, and co-wrote the second one. I, and millions of viewers, primarily come to watch this in order to get really good action scenes, and at that level, the movie delivers, primarily in the second half. It's as if this brings all of the best action scenes of the previous Jurassic franchise into a single film. The casting, which combines the stars of the original movies with the stars of the Jurassic World movies, reminded me immediately of "Star Trek Generations" where they combine the original Star Trek stars with the Star Trek The Next Generation stars. But in the end, the REAL stars of Jurassic World Dominion are of course the dinosaurs, looking more real than ever before. There is no reason that this movie needs to last 2 1/2 hours. Cut out 20-30 minutes of meaningless "plot" and you'd still have the same blockbuster summer movie smash."Jurassic Park Dominion" opened 2 weekends ago to mega-size box office (although not quite as high as "Top Gun Maverick"). The Tuesday early evening (discount) screening where I saw this at here in Cincinnati was attended okay but not great (about 10 people), and that was quite alright with me. If you are a fan of the Jurassic franchise, you'll want to keep expectations in line, and then enjoy if for the action scenes. Nothing more, nothing less.

Something or everything just seemed way off about this movie. The actors were not all there and their interactions with their environment and dinosaur counterparts were so uneven unnatural and inharmonious.The attempt at reunion of two generations of actors was too on the nose to have any impact. Most of the screen play was just a rehearsal of what has been seen before. There was also too many overly convenient set pieces to push forward an already absent plot. Too easy for the characters to get out of seemingly dangerous situations and all attempts at any tension fell flat. Also, no character development what so ever. Agreed, these are characters we are already familiar with but not a single character can have a progression, come on. The villain also is a joke as are the locusts and their pointless involvement in the story.It's not all bad because there's is outstanding visuals and some world building that was left unexplored. Not enough to save this movie from being forgettable.

The only way this film would have been worse is if the Velociraptor started speaking to Chris Pratt. Ridiculous! Joyless Cash-Grab.Lazy acting....script must have been written by a toddler who has a dinosaur figure......mixed with actors who won't get a big payout like this for the rest of their careers.......except Chris Pratt.Tragic!

Very disappointing.CGI has many flaws and the storyline is not coherent. They have tried to improve the movie by bringing the original stars from the previous movies but that did not help. The story is weak and lacks coherent.

Jurassic World Review-Pros:
The nostalgia! I watched the original Jurassic Park the night before watching this movie and I'm so glad I did because there are a lot of nods to the original film! It was really fun seeing the original cast back again for the first time in 30 years!Visual and sound. The sound editing and mixing as well as the visual effects I thought were really great, I didn't see it in XD/IMAX but I wish I did because that's the way it was meant to be seen. Especially the sound.Strong family vibes & morals. I love the relationship that all the characters have with each other. I love the role they all take in being such good parents, friends, romantic partners, etc. There were parts that were very sweet and I appreciated it, even in a dinosaur movie they don't overlook how important it is to have these bonds with other people. When the original cast meets the new cast it's almost like watching different avengers meet each other for the first time, I loved that.Cons:Kinda confusing. There are parts that are kind of confusing and you definitely need subtitles for if you are used to watching subtitles at home. If you remember Jurassic World Fallen Kingdom there are some scenes where they talk about clones and people that are clones which honestly is annoying and I wish they would've just taken all that out because it makes the science and technology of this movie more complicated.Parts that are boring. The movie doesn't take off for a while as soon as they are all in the jungle and then they all meet each other is when the movie really gets going and gets good. But you have to get past some boring scenes.Some bad acting. The villain in this movie has horrible acting. I'm not sure what the actors name is but he is Peter Parker's dad on the Amazing Spider-Man. I thought he would be great since he's great in that movie but in this one he is really really bad. It's almost like he forgot all of his lines or something. Maybe should of recast.Too long. The movie is pretty long it's 2 1/2 hours. This is the longest Jurassic movie ever done and it could of been shortened, especially during the first half part of the film.All in all I would rate it a 7/10. Purely because the original characters are so great.

This is so far the worst movie of the series. If they want to make another Jurassic movie, i hope they go back into horror root instead of this stupid action, mission impossible, fast & furious chris pratt movie.

What an amazing end to the franchise. Exactly what you expect out of a big budget summer blockbuster. 100 percent popcorn popping entertainment. Not you're saying old Jurassic Park but at the same time paying homage to the original. Loved every minute of it.

Ultimately a movie that tries to pay homage to the past movies and ends up being a reunion rather than a story. Lots of silly references to the earlier movies, crowbarred in, often leaving gaping plot holes. The movie also seems to try and cram in lots of additional species missed from the earlier films, presumably in a bid to please fans, but instead it interferes with the story or leads to poor action scenes (the final Dino fight for instance).Ultimately disjointed, it feels like half of the movie is on the cutting room floor. It surely would've worked better in 2 parts, with more story building. There are also just too many 'dumb' moments (characters teleporting to the same place, extras ignoring giant.theropods eating people right behind them, characters forgetting that guns kill dinos, I could go on).As a huge JP fan this is a sad ending to the reboot. Sadly all mindless action and reminiscing. If you turn your brain off, it's fun enough, but ultimately the worst film of them all by some margin.

The story doesn't make any sense. Too much bland and unnecessary long runtime. It's a just short 15 min movie. The movie just looped the same 15 min again and again in different places. Please showcase the hand of Chris Patt in the museum to stop tsunamis and any upcoming diseases. Just show the hand and it will automatically solve all the problems.The whole movie wasn't about dinosaurs, it's all about the stupid hand of Chris Patt.The writer is confused about what to write for the movie! Completely disaster. Jurassic Park should stop and make the movie named " The problem Solver hand".

I think critics are being too hard on this move. I'm a huge Jurassic Park fan, so seeing some of the original cast return was exciting. It's just the the plot is nonexistent and a lot of scenes seemed forced and cringey. Don't get me wrong, it's not unbearable, but I felt they could've done a lot better. It was disappointing that they focused more on the people more than they did the actual dinosaurs. Though I will admit it was cool to see different species on screen, but they didn't get enough screen time unfortunately. While I liked this one better than Fallen Kingdom and was able to enjoy it with the action scenes and nostalgia, a lot of the writing really downgraded it.

I am not going to lie, I didn't hate this movie but I also didn't love this movie. The movie flipped and flopped between multiple locations and had a ton of action scenes and it felt overwhelming at times. The movie (at times) felt like it didn't follow a singular storyline and it made it hard to follow sometimes. I thought the actors did a great job, but the movie felt like it relied on a bunch of cgi dinosaur scenes to keep it going. The movie also brought in characters from the original movies and it relied on you kind of knowing who they are to really care about them. Thus it's a little hard to care about a quarter of the cast if you haven't seen the original movies. Don't get me wrong, I love all of these movies for different reasons and this movie is not excluded from that. The movie was really well made and I really enjoyed the combination of old and new characters. I was not expecting to see the original characters throughout pretty much the whole movie and I felt it was a little awkward to throw them into this already established story and character connections in this Jurassic world storyline. I think this would be a good bookend to this movie franchise. No matter, this movie was a pretty good movie.

Just Watch it yesterday and it was quite fun movie. I love visual effect CGI Dinosaurs they make it super gorgeous but some of the Dinosaurs looks like a robot, kinda remind me of Star Wars monster. I love the cinematography looks super great and make the visual of the movie more beautiful, the story umm.. at the beginning of the movie the plot story was kinda weird but going to ending the story was getting better and better, some of the acting was like overacting? Idk it just look like not natural, and the pace to sometimes fine sometimes no. But ya this movie is still fun to watch.

Take all the things that made the original great - acting, script, cgi, score and scenery - remove that and you have this movie. What an absolute trash homage with actors phoning it in for an international audience.

This franchise should have been extinct since 1997. The original cast is here for the paycheck. The new cast is laughable. The plot is... Does this movie even have one? The CGI looks fake as hell. It's boring! Nothing specially thrilling happens. There's no payoff. Rubbish.

This short line uttered by Alan Grant presaged that epic alpha v alpha bust up between the Giganotosaurus and the Tyrannosaurus Rex. It came at the climax of this fantastic movie, bookending the Jurassic Park saga that started 30 years ago. What a phenomenal summer blockbuster bonanza this has been for people of my demographic! First, we were brought back to our need for speed, and now, within weeks, we were being brought back to the magic of our love for dinosaurs. Having Sam Neil, Laura Dern and Jeff Goldblum coming together for this (possible) one last outing was an excellent peach of a decision by the production team. This movie captured exactly the sense of wonder, thrill, excitement and adrenaline rush many of us experienced back in 1993, and it also gave today's audience what they wanted, ie, that big feast of dinosaurs from different historical timelines and geography coming together. It even managed to bring a nod to the original in a crucial scene at the end, where, just like in 1993, the greedy bad guy tried to escape with a container of dinosaur DNA, got stuck, tried to get away, but eventually was confronted and killed by a group of Dilophosaurus. That is the charm of this movie, and I was still trying to catch my breath when the credits were rolling.This is going to be a movie summer many will remember!

If I wasn't such a huge fan of dinosaurs and held the original Jurassic Park (and 2+3, I know sue me) then this would've been given 6 stars. I enjoyed seeing the dinosaurs that was probably my favourite part of the movie, that and Alan Grant of course, that's when they were on screen anyway and not giant locus. It definitely lacked that feel of dinosaurs being everywhere overall as they decided to make it cricket focused instead for some reason and to have a big bad be the science corporations and not the dinosaurs running around which is what I would have preferred. The movie was also kind of messy with many plots going on all at once with some cheesy dialogue thrown in. I wanted to love this movie but they made a really uninteresting plot that still could've been better. The dinosaurs were great though I loved seeing all the unique species to this movie and even got some surprises in there too. I loved seeing the dinosaurs around the real world and co existing or at least trying to, I thought that made for a really unique couple of scenes. I definitely enjoyed the movie but if I wanted to watch it again I'd probably skip to the scenes with the dinosaurs I liked as the plot was all over the place. To be fair I only come to see dinosaurs in these movies and action scenes of sorts and I definitely got them but overall it was only brief moments in the entirety of the movie. I hope they do more and make a movie about the dinosaurs living among the humans more. I do have to say the cinematography with the dinosaurs was really beautiful on the screen and the music was great which I found out at the end to be the same person who did the Batman music. Anyway for now I'll stick to the original trilogy.

Except the action sequences because the noise wouldn't let me, I slept most of the time. Actors have acted pathetically. Two stars for the bike chase sequence, rest is all seen multiple times before. Stop making Jurassic movies.

Spoiler free review:There have been a lot of mixed reviews for this one, including a 29% rotten tomato score from critics.I've just finished watching this and I have to say, I thoroughly enjoyed it. Now I do need to point out that if plot holes, unrealistic set pieces, and an underdeveloped political/economic/social world are issues, then please avoid films with dinosaurs in the modern world.I also need to state that my expectations for dinosaur movies are:1. Dinosaurs.2. Dinosaurs fighting each other.3. Dinosaurs eating people.4. Pretty people to look at.I was not disappointed.It's mad fun, it's daft in places, it's thrilling, there are some great throwback moments. It's fantastic to see the cast together and overall, it's a great conclusion to the franchise ...so far.

How bad of a script writer/director do you have to be to screw up everyone's favorite creatures of all time - dinosaurs! It's so simple, just show us the dinosaurs, have the dinosaurs battle the humans, have the dinosaurs battle each other for a bit, have the humans overcome their differences and team up to save the day. Boom, blockbuster done.Instead this movie mostly separates the humans from the dinosaurs, gives us a bunch of disparate human-centric plot lines that never seem to meet up or gel with each other played by too many improperly introduced characters with bit parts. Throw in some no-depth characters like the bratty teen girl that doesn't listen to anyone and makes dumb decisions that get her kidnapped, villains that are evil just for the sake of being evil, and a 'rough and tumble' bush pilot that looks like she just spent 6 hours in the salon chair getting her hair and colored contact lenses just right.When we do see dinosaurs it's too often not the big and fearsome ones we want. Instead we get a lot of little baby robo-dinosaurs where I can practically see someone holding a remote off screen to move the head of a marble-eyed, unblinking dino-doll, and then to top it off we get...dino-locusts? Gee, how thrilling.I gave it a 3 for the sake of classy Sam Neil who was about the only person who didn't make me cringe, but versus what this should have been and pretty easily could have been, it's more like a minus three. What a shameful way to end a series that started with one of the greatest action movies of the 1990s.

I think others have been to harsh. Yes, it's familiar territory but well edited, good acting and some laughs (spot 'The Shining' reference). I thought the running time would be too long but it my attention throughout. Screen time is well shared among the cast and the sub plots work well together. Nice to see Laura and Sam get together at the end and and Isabella Sermon and Wanda deWise are very watchable. Some people really need to chill out and just eat their popcorn...

I personally thought that this final chapter was done amazingly.The live action dinosaurs and CGI versions of the dinosaurs were ABSOLUTELY INCREDIBLE. They all looked so real. This movie also had THE MOST scenes with the live action puppet versions of the DINO's... and all together the most scenes with dinosaurs than any other previous movie.I see many reviews complaining about the "lack of" story about dinosaurs... that's completely not true in any fashion. They do have a few storylines consisting of several non important stories that bring ALL the characters together in the final act. But how much more could the story tellers teach us about these dinosaurs we've seen and studied since the original Jurassic Park in 1993??!!?? We know how they were made and how they've evolved the past 29 years.In closing... THIS MOVIE WAS VISUALLY STUNNING, SCARY, & BEAUTIFULLY PUT TOGETHER. The story was great for each and every character. A beautiful ending to an amazing franchise that has spanned over almost 30 years.I'm very excited where they will take this franchise next??!! I hope they continue with a new storyline and new characters in the next 5 years!If you're a fan of any Jurassic movie... you will definitely love this action filled, dinosaur packed finale! Trust me, you'll be glad you got to see this in the theater and on the big screen! We went to IMAX to see the film this evening.

Jurassic World: Dominion is a messy, but fun movie. Seeing the old and new cast and characters interact was just awesome, but the many plotpoints get overwhelming at times, and make it hard to follow along with the story. The dinosaurs don't really get the spotlight, as the movie has a Political Theme going on with life living with the Dinosaurs. The size and scope is the biggest we've ever gotten from a Jurassic Movie, spanning to different continents and locations, which makes for some fun scenes with Dinosaur Chases and Dinosaur. Overall, not what I had in mind to be the epic conclusion to the saga, but still enjoyable. So, as the tagline for this review I have to call it fun but really flawed. It didn't bore me in any way, and I was still able to enjoy the movie and have fun with it.. but it had a HECK TON of Problems.

I finally watched this movie after 3 years since it got released in the cinemas. And I must say that it was so cool to see the old cost reunite for one more big adventure. It was very nostalgic, having our favourite characters from the first movie all in threat with the new characters. I didn't recognise the character of Maisie in this movie. As she grew up quite a bit from the last movie, the actual sequences were also well done and having some brief cameos from other characters from the other movies was really cruel and fun. Add some of the Dino action sequences, revealing intents, especially that one dive scene in depths underground train bank. Oh, my gosh, that was terrifying. And a big call back to the first one, but apart from the cool action scenes and the fact that we had our old cast back, this movie was a little bit like lustre when it came to the script, I found my mind wandering at times I don't think it is the best Jurassic Parker,/world. Movie, I think I prefer the lover ones. It is better than the lost world. I'm probably deferred one but it's still the lower event. I give this movie a seven out of dead. I recommend it for the cool action scenes.

There have been better Jurassic movies... And there have been worse. I was hoping 'Dominion' would stop trying to take this whole "dinosaurs in modern society" schtick too seriously. I mean, seriously, this plotline is taken way too seriously. With this silly plotline, at least make it a comedic movie or something. I cringed every time I saw one of the characters in imminent danger of being attacked by a dinosaur simply raise their hand as if magically all dinosaurs will obey that gesture and not eat them.Dinosaurs that hunt and eat people are everywhere, and the film's ending message is that we'll just have to learn to co-exist. Seriously??? That's never going to work when every facet of life is disrupted by dinosaurs that can hunt you down at kill you at any moment without warning. Their impact on the global food chain would not bode well for the planet's well-being either. And the constant threat of flying pterodactyl's on the aviation industry?? Need I go on??...The only realistic ending to save the planet would be to exterminate each and every dinosaur. As Jeff Goldblum's character said in the first JP film, "dinosaurs had their shot already". But hey, killing all the dino's would make for a boring movie. So, insert old JP actors with the new ones for nostalgia, then turn off your brain and watch CGI dinosaurs happily co-exist with humans in the end.

Bringing back the original cast of Jurassic Park works very well in this film and is one of the rare good things about this movie.
